highlights.representative_text: So step out of the content of the conversation--which is generally focused on strategies--and explore the purposes behind them.

highlights.representative_text: Although it's difficult to describe the specific order of events in an interaction as fluid as a crucial conversation, we do know one thing for certain: Skilled people Start with Heart.

highlights.representative_text: When friends, loved ones, or colleagues move away from healthy dialogue (freely adding to the pool of meaning)--either forcing their opinions into the pool or purposefully keeping their ideas out of the pool--they immediately turn their attention to whether or not others feel safe.

highlights.representative_text: We also have to be willing to verbalize this commitment even when our partner seems committed to winning. We act on faith that our partner is stuck in silence or violence because he or she feels unsafe. We assume that if we build more safety--by demonstrating our commitment to finding a Mutual Purpose--the other person will feel more confident that dialogue could be a productive avenue.

highlights.representative_text: When people feel disrespected, they become highly charged. Their emotions turn from fear to anger.

highlights.representative_text: If this belief is incorrect, use Contrasting to clarify what you don't and do believe.

highlights.representative_text: Do others believe I respect them?

highlights.representative_text: People who are gifted at dialogue keep a constant vigil on safety. They pay attention to the content--that's a given--and they watch for signs that people are afraid.

highlights.representative_text: Our motives usually change without any conscious thought on our part. When adrenaline does our thinking for us, our motives flow with the chemical tide.

highlights.representative_text: When people misunderstand and you start arguing over the misunderstanding, stop. Use Contrasting. Explain what you don't mean until you've restored safety. Then return to the conversation. Safety first.
highlights.selected_text: When people misunderstand and you start arguing over the misunderstanding, stop. Use Contrasting. Explain what you don't mean until you've restored safety. Then return to the conversation. Safety first.

highlights.representative_text: Crucial Conversation n A discussion between two or more people where (1) stakes are high, (2) opinions vary, and (3) emotions run strong.
highlights.selected_text: Crucial Conversation n A discussion between two or more people where (1) stakes are high, (2) opinions vary, and (3) emotions run strong.

highlights.representative_text: Invent a Mutual Purpose. If after clarifying everyone's purposes you are still at odds, see if you can invent a higher or longer-term purpose that is more motivating than the ones that keep you in conflict.
highlights.selected_text: Purpose. If after clarifying everyone's purposes you are still at odds, see if you can invent a higher or longer-term purpose that is more motivating than the ones that keep you in conflict

highlights.representative_text: When it comes to risky, controversial, and emotional conversations, skilled people find a way to get all relevant information (from themselves and others) out into the open.
highlights.selected_text: When it comes to risky, controversial, and emotional conversations, skilled people find a way to get all relevant information (from themselves and others) out into the open.

highlights.representative_text: Afraid to confront an individual, we blame an entire team for a problem--hoping the message will hit the right target.
highlights.selected_text: Afraid to confront an individual, we blame an entire team for a problem

highlights.representative_text: Focus on What You Really Want
highlights.selected_text: Focus on What You Really Want

highlights.representative_text: Ask yourself the Start with Heart questions: What do I want for me? What do I want for others? What do I want for the relationship?
highlights.selected_text: Start with Heart questions: What do I want for me? What do I want for others? What do I want for the relationship?

highlights.representative_text: People who routinely hold crucial conversations and hold them well are able to express controversial and even risky opinions in a way that gets heard.
highlights.selected_text: People who routinely hold crucial conversations and hold them well are able to express controversial and even risky opinions in a way that gets heard

highlights.representative_text: Whatever they are, learn to look at them as signs to step back, slow down, and Start with Heart before things get out of hand.

highlights.representative_text: For instance, high performers know how to stand up to the boss without committing career suicide.

highlights.representative_text: We Start with Heart by committing to stay in the conversation until we come up with a solution that serves a purpose we both share.

highlights.representative_text: Once you've created your emotions, you have only two options: You can act on them or be acted on by them.

highlights.representative_text: You and only you create your emotions.

highlights.representative_text: The best don't play games. They know that dialogue is the free flow of meaning--with no pretending, sugarcoating, or faking. So they do something completely different. They step out of the content of the conversation, make it safe, and then step back in.

highlights.representative_text: As people begin to feel unsafe, they start down one of two unhealthy paths. They move either to silence (withholding meaning from the pool) or to violence (trying to force meaning in the pool).

highlights.representative_text: As everyone on the team began to explain his or her opinion, people formed a more clear and complete picture of the circumstances.

highlights.representative_text: When you do this, new options become possible. When you release your grip on your strategy and focus on your real purpose, you open up the possibility of finding new alternatives that can serve Mutual Purpose.

highlights.representative_text: In truth, when we face crucial conversations, we can do one of three things: We can avoid them. We can face them and handle them poorly. We can face them and handle them well.
highlights.selected_text: In truth, when we face crucial conversations, we can do one of three things: We can avoid them. We can face them and handle them poorly. We can face them and handle them well.

highlights.representative_text: When we recognize that we all have weaknesses, it's easier to find a way to respect others. When we do this, we feel a kinship, a sense of mutuality between ourselves and even the thorniest of people.

underlines.representative_text: We (the authors) didn’t always spend our time noodling over crucial conversations.
Crucial conversations often go awry not because of the content of the conversation, but because others believe that the painful and pointed content means that you have a malicious intent.
When people purposefully withhold meaning from one another, individually smart people can do collectively stupid things.
The “sins” of others were different from their own more because of the role they played than because of a fundamental blight on their character.

To break from this insidious cycle, Learn to Look.
We discredit others, hoping people won’t believe their arguments.
In order to justify an especially sordid behavior, we suggest that we’re caught between two distasteful options.
Here’s the problem we have to fix: When we find ourselves at an impasse, it’s because we’re asking for one thing and the other person is asking for something else.
Not everyone in prison is a career criminal who was born into a horrible family, then shaped by abuse and neglect into a seething sociopath.
We usually lose any semblance of social sensitivity when we become so consumed with ideas and causes that we lose track of what we’re doing.
In Odd Couple parlance, you’re Felix and he’s Oscar.
